content: you know I don't do miniature painting videos very often maybe only a handful
in my entire history but when you have a chance to paint demo Gorgon you paint
demo Gorgon this is a really cool model and a case study in why if you're not
into painting miniatures I think you should try it
everyone why lock here thank you for joining me today we're gonna paint demo
Gorgon I guess this was limited to 1500 this model was loaned to me by my
neighbor to paint up he's in my D&D campaign but I'm gonna assume that
you've never painted a model before alright so this video may be a little
bit tedious at parts for those of you who are familiar with any sort of
miniature painting but just in case to show you how fun and easy can be I think
I only spent like two hours of actual bench time excluding dry time to paint
this guy up and get this result so walk you through how I did it let's go paint
the model and remember that our sponsor is hero's horde for you 3d printers out
there excellent selection including Altru tiles lines so to begin with I've
already assembled him and spray primed him black then I took it outside and
with some gray primer I just sprayed top down to give it a nice zenith fill start
this is sometimes called pre shading and with the methods we're using it's not
totally necessary but it will have a subtle effect on the overall result at
the end you'll see here it is dry inside under some better lighting you can see
already it's done a lot of shading actually looks pretty cool as is right
so you can imagine if you paint thinly over this with color you're gonna get a
result with some nice depth and I will be using by AO paints throughout this
video and the main scheme is centered around a basic looking green a light
lime looking green and a bone white and to the airbrush with that light green
which is Verde escort pinna I'm using an I wanna H pcs and there's
links in the video description below with all the supplies that I recommend
mixing the paint to the consistency of whole milk and you can use just water to
water it down but it helps to have some flow improver and the key especially
with light colors is don't try to get one coat coverage I think I did two or
three passes on the whole body here with this green and it still only took like
five minutes because when you lay it on thin it dries almost instantly here it
is a few minutes later all the coats done and dry and you can see nice full
coverage but also it looks slightly shaded right so that pre-shading we did
coming through just a little bit next up I'm going to do all the fur on the
and for this I'm going to use a light brown tannish color and again don't try
to get one coat coverage with an airbrush as tempting as it may be don't
do it also in the tentacles and the tail at an extreme angle I spritzed just a
very very light dusting of this tan color you can see it's really not much
at all and the hope here is that it just adds a little differentiation brings a
little closer to that olive color that we see on the box next up I loaded up
that standard green I think it's called sip green and hit the under sides of
things select the biceps here the entire torso underneath the legs shooting
upwards from underneath at the scales and this is just gonna further enhance
the depth and the shadows and where the light is coming from yeah so again that
seems subtle and unnecessary but look at the model now compared to a moment to go
really has some depth to it and we haven't even done any washing or
highlighting yet now it's finally to a standard good old fashioned brush to put
on this bone white color on the under sides of the tentacles two thin coats is
the way to go with these nice model paints and really with any paint but
especially on miniatures so that you don't clog up details dipping the brush
in water before you dip it in the paint is an easy way to thin it pretty much
the proper amount you can also add water to your pallet ahead of time but I don't
do that I just have a heavily loaded brush with water and basically let the
mixing happen at the moment it hits the model I also base coated the teeth and
all of his claws down below and with an orange e Brown sort of color base coated
the tongue again just trying to mimic the boxart here now I'm at an awkward
angle for filming this whole thing so my techniques aren't always what you should
do like my hand is kind of turned away from the model awkwardly right now but
you can see I have my pinky finger touching the model that creates a
tremendous amount of stability for your hand it gives you a lot more control
whenever you do in fine detail painting or miniature painting it's a really good
idea to do that touch your pinky to the model or to your other pinky if you're
holding the model with both hands then I took a black-and-gray mixed him
up 5050 and base coated all these little spikes on him
and now it's time to wash a wash is basically a very thin pigment rich
mixture it can be paint that's just watered-down but ideally you have
dedicated products like these that are actual pigment rich inks mixed with
various flow improvers for this guy I chose to go with army painter soft tone
it's a brown wash but it's a very light brown and I think it'll go well to tie
these two main color schemes I have going on the green in the tan it'll tie
them together really well so I just slide this over the entire body
everything now a product like this I generally do not water down it's already
the consistency that it should be if it's any thinner it's not going to give
a meaningful deep color and all the nooks and crannies that it sinks into
also for a highly vertical model like this it might run down and pool at the
bottom and just bleed off of the model now you can see in real time how this
just goes right into the details they suck them up and it really makes the
model start to pop I'm just gonna go apply this over the entire thing don't
be afraid with washes they dry subtler than they look when they're wet
sometimes by a lot so it may look really dark now but wait till it dries and this
will take a good solid hour to dry so for example here it is totally done
being washed I just finished it's still very wet we'll get some close-ups you
can see how it's sunk into cracks it's pooled kind of nicely in places where I
want it to subtly changing the character of those green scales to sort of an
olive but now here it is dry much subtler right still looks nicely tied
together unfortunately this has really revealed that mold line there crosses
back which is disappointing I didn't see that before or alright now I need to
make an adjustment I feel that the fur is a little bit bleached out it's not as
vibrant as I would like want to add some saturation so I just figured I would try
this reddish brown dark flesh tone and mix it with some army painter strong
tone mix that equal parts together along with an equal part of water to make a
nice rich glaze and then I just dab that all over the fur mostly in the central
parts to sort of create a gradient and again this is gonna be a lot more subtle
when it dries and there we go much better much richer
color which I like I'm not afraid of colors I don't think you should be
either I think miniatures should really pop so
even if they don't look realistic whatever color is fun let's switch gears
a little bit and work on the base first solid coat with sort of a lighter gray I
don't remember what it was was probably a cheap craft paint actually two thin
coats being patient for dry times between each and we get a nice beautiful
smooth matte finish here so I'm going to use some purple tone this is a wash and
I apply this liberally to all of the stonework the pillars and the arches and
the stuff that he's grabbing on to and the stuff that's busted up on the ground
I just slathered it on there again not watering it down using it right out of
the bottle
followed by some dark tone this is just a black wash and he hid all the rest of
the base everything that wasn't you know fallen stone when applying washes it's a
good idea to use a soft bristle brush with fairly long bristles in a round
shape as opposed to a pointed tip so take a look at the brush I'm using here
here's a good look at it wet nice and beautiful and saturated and here they
are dry wonderful I love these army painter washes now for
some dry brushing dry brushing is a technique where you have a dry brush and
then you dip it in a bit of paint and then you work the paint right back off
onto the pallet so there's just a trace amount left on the bristles then you
strike at the piece lightly at varying angles and let the detail of the model
pick the paint off of the bristles for you do this lightly you can always add
more but you can't take it off so I'm using a light gray here and I'm dry
brushing all the stuff that I just shaded the purple and the ground and
this is a super easy way to highlight a model very fast took about 90 seconds to
dry brush the whole base also going to return to that original S corp inna
green and do some dry brushing on the scales and notice that the brush I'm
only picking it upwards I'm not going back downwards and this is so that only
those leading edges of the scales will catch the light green and it won't go
over the main surface and certainly not into the cracks that we just shaded also
back to that original bone white for the underside of the tentacles and I dry
brush those as well you can see in real time how this highlights the model and
bring some life back to it because washes do tend to dull things down a lot
so no matter what you're doing at what level you're painting it's almost always
a good idea to do some highlighting after you've washed or shaded back to
that original gray that I had mixed with the black and just picking out the tips
of all the spikes on his back and his shoulders now it's time to do some
yellows and yellow is the worst color to paint with it generally it doesn't
matter what quality what brand its coverage is terrible
so it's helpful to lay down white first and then paint yellow over that so it's
back to the airbrush and I'm gonna do that bloom that's in the middle of his
chest where the evil is radiating out or whatever that is from the boxart I'm
also gonna stage the eyes and the nostrils with white then we'll load in
the Sun yellow color so it's not a true yellow it's sort of like a golden ish
yellow and we'll do up the chest and then the eye sockets and the nose by the
way this wouldn't really be possible with a super cheap you know twenty
dollar airbrush those generally cannot draw a fine bead up close like this and
don't have that amount of control and then it's back to white to hit that
bloom in the middle and make it start to glow and finally with a reddish orange
sort of color I painted the eyes and I used the finest brush I have for this a
Windsor Newton series 7 I think it's a triple lot you don't need that but you
need something with a real fine point lastly I'm gonna do a nice protective
clear coat this krylon crystal clear flat unlike all other matte sealants
I've tried this one actually dries true matte so I highly recommend it
so hopefully this demonstrates to you the power of an airbrush for doing base
coating it literally reduces the amount of time 99% not exaggerating also you
notice I didn't do a single edge highlight or pin recess washing this
entire thing all I did was the absolute basic introductory level techniques
associated with miniature painting to get a pretty good result this is perfect
I'm running out of the abyss right now we're halfway through I expect to start
using this model a lot so what do you think did I nail the boxart
or not you know in my mind's eye I had always pictured emmamorgan as being like
black and red but this is alright it pops nicely another point I'll share is
consider the fur I did not dry brush the fur that's because I had a really light
color on there for the base coat before I washed now the brighter your color is
before the wash obviously the brighter the Peaks will be after it dries we know
that washes will dull and darken the current state of the
paint but if the original state of the paint was really bright well you can get
away without having to highlight it and if there's one point that I hope you
take away from this it's that triangle of power concept use your pinky finger
to create stability when you're doing miniature painting if you enjoy ha being
and crafting for your tabletop gaming make sure you come and find our
community 30,000 strong on Facebook the tabletop crafters guild we'd love to
have you and if you enjoyed this particular video here's two others that
I think you'll also like so I am why lock thanks for joining me today make
things and play games
